questions.text:
A 61-year-old man who underwent bilateral total-knee arthroplasty 10 years ago for osteoarthritis is hospitalized with a 2-day history of fever, as well as painful swelling of his right thigh.
On admission, his temperature is 38.3°C. He has a fluctuant nodular lesion with surrounding cellulitis on his right thigh but no knee pain or erythema.
The thigh lesion is incised and drained. Initial wound cultures and one of two blood culture sets grow methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.
The patient defervesces after treatment with vancomycin, and the thigh lesion improves. A transesophageal echocardiogram reveals no vegetations. Repeat blood cultures, drawn 2 days later, are negative.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia has a high rate of recurrence if inadequately treated. The recommended therapy is intravenous vancomycin or daptomycin, given for at least 2 weeks in patients with uncomplicated MRSA bacteremia — and 4 to 6 weeks in those with complicated MRSA bacteremia.

Patients are considered to have uncomplicated MRSA bacteremia if they meet all of the following criteria:

• Blood cultures are positive for MRSA
• Endocarditis has been excluded
• The patient has no implanted prostheses
• Follow-up blood cultures obtained 2 to 4 days after the initial set do not grow MRSA
• The patient defervesces within 72 hours after initiating effective therapy
• There is no evidence of metastatic sites of infection

Key learning point: The preferred treatment for a patient with an arthroplasty who has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia is intravenous vancomycin or daptomycin for 4 to 6 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

The recommended therapy for complicated MRSA bacteremia is intravenous vancomycin or daptomycin for 4 to 6 weeks, not 8 weeks.

C) INCORRECT:

Although oral therapy with linezolid is appropriate for treating MRSA skin and soft-tissue infections, it is not recommended as first-line therapy for bacteremia.

D) INCORRECT:

The recommended therapy for complicated MRSA bacteremia, such as in patients with prosthetic joints, is intravenous vancomycin or daptomycin for 4 to 6 weeks, not 2 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Although oral therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is appropriate for treating MRSA skin and soft-tissue infections, it is not recommended as first-line therapy for bacteremia.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman has a history of lupus nephritis with end-stage kidney disease. While undergoing hemodialysis yesterday through the tunneled catheter in her right subclavian vein, she developed a fever, chills, and nausea with dizziness. Her vital signs showed a temperature of 39.3°C, a blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg, a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Her dialysis was discontinued early, she was given acetaminophen and a bolus of fluid, and blood cultures were taken. Her physical examination was significant only for erythema around the entry site of her catheter; there was no purulent drainage. She was sent to radiology for removal of the catheter and was then discharged home in stable condition.
Today, her blood cultures are positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. She is admitted to the hospital. A transesophageal echocardiogram reveals no evidence of endocarditis. She has no other prosthetic devices.
Which one of the following antibiotics is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin and is not active against MRSA.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is often used to treat MRSA skin and soft-tissue infections, particularly in the outpatient setting. However, in a randomized study of people who inject drugs and were hospitalized with serious S. aureus infections, vancomycin was superior to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Treatment failure in the trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole group mostly occurred in patients with tricuspid valve endocarditis and only in those with methicillin-susceptible infections; nevertheless, given this study’s findings and clinical experience, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is rarely used to treat S. aureus bacteremia.

C) CORRECT:

The first-line therapy for uncomplicated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia is intravenous vancomycin. In patients on hemodialysis, the vancomycin should be administered after hemodialysis. Troughs should be kept between 15 and 20 μg/mL.

Daptomycin is an appropriate alternative to vancomycin and has an important role, particularly in patients who cannot tolerate or are allergic to vancomycin or who have a MRSA isolate with a high vancomycin minimum inhibitory concentration.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for uncomplicated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia is intravenous vancomycin.

D) INCORRECT:

Tigecycline is not an appropriate therapy for MRSA bacteremia because it has bacteriostatic, rather than bactericidal, activity against MRSA. Furthermore, tigecycline does not achieve high concentrations in the blood.

E) INCORRECT:

Linezolid is not an appropriate therapy for MRSA bacteremia because it has bacteriostatic, rather than bactericidal, activity against MRSA.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man is on postoperative day 2 following a segmental colectomy. He began experiencing chills and shaking rigors last night. He denies cough or urinary symptoms. The surgical wound site is slightly erythematous with minimal serous drainage. Blood cultures have been drawn; results are pending. By the following morning, he develops confusion, persistent high fever, and a blood pressure of 95/60 mm Hg (see lab result).


Heart rate
120/min


Blood pressure
110/68 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
20/min


Temperature
38.9°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
15 × 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant hyperthermia typically occurs during or immediately after exposure to triggering anesthetics, presenting with muscle rigidity, hypercarbia, and acidosis. The patient's symptoms began on postoperative day 2, and the elevated white blood cell count and wound erythema suggest infection, not a calcium regulation disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism risk increases postoperatively, but it usually presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and hypoxemia. The presence of rigors, confusion, and fever, along with leukocytosis and wound erythema, indicates an infectious process rather than a thromboembolic event.

C) CORRECT:

Sepsis manifests with systemic inflammatory response syndrome due to infection. In this patient, the presence of chills, rigors, and localized wound erythema suggests a transition from localized infection to systemic involvement. The development of high fever, confusion, and hypotension indicates dysregulated inflammatory response, leading to impaired tissue perfusion. An elevated white blood cell count supports active infection. The progression from localized signs to systemic symptoms is characteristic of bacteremia advancing to sepsis, where cytokine release and endothelial dysfunction occur.

Key learning point: Bacteraemia can occur following surgical procedures and may present with chills and rigors; it is important to monitor for signs of progression to sepsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid storm can present with fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status, but it typically occurs in patients with hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by tremor, diaphoresis, and gastrointestinal symptoms, which are absent here. The postoperative context and leukocytosis suggest an infectious process rather than a thyroid-mediated state.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of IV drug use presents to the ED with fever, rigors, and malaise for 3 days. Physical examination reveals multiple track marks on his arms and a 3-cm erythematous, tender area on his right forearm. He is febrile and mildly hypotensive. Which of the following antibiotics should be included as part of empiric treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that provides excellent gram-negative and some gram-positive coverage, but it has no activity against MRSA.

B) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin-tazobactam provides broad-spectrum coverage against gram-negative bacteria and some gram-positive organisms, but it does not have reliable activity against MRSA.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic primarily used for atypical pathogens and some gram-positive organisms, but it has poor activity against Staphylococcus aureus and is not appropriate for suspected bacteremia in this clinical context.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Vancomycin is the appropriate empiric choice for suspected MRSA bacteremia, which is likely in this patient with a history of IV drug use.

E) INCORRECT:

Cefazolin is effective against methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus but has no activity against MRSA.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and altered mental status that developed over the past 24 hours. His medical history includes diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, and a prosthetic hip joint placed 3 months ago. On examination, he is febrile and hypotensive, and has an erythematous and mildly tender surgical wound over his left hip. Based on his presentation and risk factors, which pathogen is most likely responsible for his bloodstream infection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is primarily associated with urinary tract infections, inflammatory bowel disease, and colorectal cancer as predisposing factors for bloodstream infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is most commonly associated with urinary tract infections and intraabdominal pathology as sources for bloodstream infection and is not the most likely cause in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae typically causes respiratory tract infections and meningitis as primary sites of infection and would not be the most likely cause of bacteremia in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bedridden patients, and prolonged hospitalization and would not be the most likely cause in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Staphylococcus aureus is typically associated with prosthetic implants, skin and soft tissue infections, central venous catheters, and vertebral osteomyelitis.
